The problem is the camera isnâ€™t communicating to the lens so the lens is spinning and not focusing . Itâ€™s cranking the focus motor non stop

Auto Focus

Oof. AF can be finicky, depending on the camera and lens, and combination of the two. Most folks set the lens focus manually. Which can be a pain but... also illustrates why you want a team. More on that later.

â€”> I had set it manual but was getting a blurry image so I turned to AF to test it and thatâ€™s when I realized there was something wrong with the lens and camera connection. 

I know some of the newer sony dslr cameras and lenses have really awesome, eyeball-tracking auto focus. You just need to make sure the af is set to the proper mode, and that the lens is compatible with live/continuous af with that specific camera model. For $1500, your camera likely only has the most rudimentary of AF systems, designed for shooting stills.  If the af wont work, theres no ac and you canâ€™t pull focus, set it to manual focus. Shoot it at a deep stop, block scenes and compose shots so that they donâ€™t require you to change focus very often. Thats what was done in the old days!


â€”â€”> Yes! 

If you can, re-shoot the stuff thatâ€™s got distracting AF changes in the middle of the clips you need. No shame in that, tech issues happen all the time on big budget projects too. Ask Spielberg about the mechanical sharks!

Maybe even offer points (cut of the profits) if it does really really well. Like millions of dollars well. But most DPâ€™s starting out will shoot for free if they can get good reel material. Same for actors! Think of it like barter. Money isnâ€™t real, connections and favors are.
